bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, September 13, 1950

div1.p: Siler provides more details concerning Kean's medical condition before his death. Siler will confer with Lawrence Reed about Blossom's house in Pennsylvania, but believes it has been rented, and that she is to live with Lawrence after her discharge from the hospital.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, September 13, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
-----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
September 13, 1950
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I wrote you on September 12th concerning a number of matters. Since writing
that letter I have been able to talk with Col. Kimborough, head of the Urological
Service at Walter Reed, and I am afraid that I gave you incorrect information on
some points. Col. Kimborough tells me that when General Kean was admitted to the
hospital he had complete retention and it was necessary to use a catheter to keep
the bladder emptied. Col. Kimborough was away from the hospital for a few days
after Gen. Kean was admitted and during this absence a compley survey was made of
Gen. Kean's general physical condition. When Kimborough returned it was decided
that it would not be possible to remove the prostate under any circumstances on
account of Gen. Kean's age and the condition of his heart. It was felt, however,
that something would have to be done to relieve the constant retention and a
suprapubic custostomy was carried out under local anesthesia. Unfortunately Gen.
Kean had a stroke subsequent to the operation and this was complicated by pneumonia
which required use of an oxygen tent for several days.

With further reference to Blossom Reed's letter to you, I think you can dis-
regard it entirely as it was written at a time when Blossom was not thining pro-
perly. Sha has been in the Psychopathic Ward at Walter Reed for a week or more
and during the past three days her mental condition has improved to some extent
although she is still very greatly confused. It is my intention to go out and see
her when she is somewhat better and I will write you later concerning her condition.
As I have already written you, she is receiving and will continue to receive the
monthly annuity of $84 from the Walter Reed Memorial Association. I shall also
take up with General Reed the question of her property at Blue Ridge Summit. I do
know that her home up there has been rented and General Reed expects to have her
live with him after she is released from the hospital. If I receive any further
information concerning her financial problems, I will pass it along to you in the
near future.

We hope that it will be possible for you to attend the annual meeting this
year. It will of course be necessary for us to elect a new President and also two
new members of the Board as both General Kean and Dr. L. O. Haward have died re-
cently.

I went down to Ft. McNair a few days ago and the grass around the marker is
now looking quite well and I will soon have the photograph made and send you one.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler
Col., (MC), U.S.A., Ret'd jfs k
